Award.AwardTitle: Mathematics and Control of Systemic and High-Frequency Trading Risks
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the dependence structure among defaults of financial institutions is of fundamental importance for the design of policies aiming to enhance financial stability. Contractual, legal, and business relationships among firms may act as a conduit for the transmission and amplification of risks. Under scenarios of financial distress, spillover effects on business counterparties and more broadly on the real economic sectors can be significant. It is thus fundamentally important that financial institutions, holding large portfolios of fixed income securities, can quantify these risks and their systemic implications before making hedging and investment decisions. Equally important for financial stability is to explain the huge volatility spikes of asset prices, periodically observed during flash crash events in markets dominated by high-frequency traders. If these events were happening to a too-big-to-fail institution, the market could be wrecked and government bailout would be necessary, with enormous consequences on taxpayers.

This project will develop stochastic control techniques for solving fixed income portfolio selection problems in the presence of contagion risk, and analyzing intraday liquidity and price dynamics in high-frequency trading markets. In the first part of the project, the investigator will study recursive systems of nonlinear parabolic partial differential equations arising in the optimal selection and hedging of fixed income portfolios. In the second part of the project, he will develop new numerical techniques for analyzing second order forward-backward stochastic differential equations with jumps, a class of equations arising naturally in high frequency trading when controlling for the inventory risk. The unique structure of these problems will present new mathematical challenges in stochastic analysis, including the study of fully nonlinear partial integro-differential equations, second order forward-backward stochastic differential equations with jumps, and stochastic games associated with these equations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This integrated research and education proposal developed stochastic control techniques for (i) solving portfolio selection problems accounting for  systemic risk, time varying investor's preferences, and multi-agent interactions, and (II) understanding the price formation process in high-frequency trading markets populated by large institutions with urgent trading needs.

From a methodological perspective, the proposed research advanced knowledge in the area of parabolic partial differential equations, and infinite horizon backward stochastic differential equations with jump-drive dynamics. It also contributed to the design of solution methods to analyze nonzero sum stochastic dynamic games driven by the interaction of agents competing for liquidity. Moreover, the proposed research led to the design of robust portfolio management techniques to deal with risk-sensitive control problems where the underlying securities have jump-diffusion dynamics and change state when bankruptcy events occur.

From an applied perspective, the proposed research allowed understanding  how to manage portfolios which are sensitive to credit events, such as the systemic risk phenomena observed during the last 2007-2009 financial crisis. The proposed research also developed the first human-machine investment framework which can guide portfolio allocation decisions of robo-advisor firms. Those firms are being sought after increasingly more by households looking for personalized advice or wealth management. Moreover, the research shed light on the time dimension of liquidity in high-frequency trading market. This is widely agreed to be a significant source of risk faced by portfolio managers and market makers as positions liquidated during periods of distress may be significant and span several hours or even days. Nevertheless, the framework proposed by the PI is the first to rigorously treated and analyze the dynamics of liquidity risk.

The PI has trained both doctoral and post-doctoral students by involving them in the research projects carried out as a part of this proposal. This led to academic advancements, such as Dr. Xu Sun who got a tenure track job at the University of Florida; increased visibility through participation at national and international conferences for the post-doctoral scholars Sveinn Olafsson and Hongzhong Zhang. Part of the material developed in this proposal has also been incorporated in the graduate level class "Networks: Games, Contagion, and Control" taught by the PI in his home department in the years 2017, 2018, and 2019.

The results of this research have been communicated above and beyond the research community, attracting the attention of regulators and consulting companies which offer advices on the execution quality of portfolio managers and which perform automated investment on behalf of clients.  The results of this research have been published in top quality journals of applied mathematics, financial mathematics, as well as mathematics of operations research and management science.
